When January rolls around, there’s a stirring again, a sense of something waking, but even then, the logs remain few. February, too, offers no explanation for the dearth that lingers. It is the nature of things to begin with vigor, then wane, and so we sought to light a fire anew with the Carpool Challenge Week come March, a swift campaign that brought some life back to the endeavor. Yet the real test lay in keeping that spark alive against the cold reality of breaks and holidays that come with the world of learning.

And there’s the rub, for the heart of man yearns for the open road, the promise of freedom that sits behind the wheel of a car. It is a thing woven deep in the fabric of our lives. To coax folks toward a different path, we offered prizes, small treasures from the world nearby—a meal, a coffee, a book from the shop on the corner. But it is a thought that lingers, what might have been with grander prizes, a fine bicycle, perhaps, or even a car that whispers of the future with its silent engine. The prizes we gave did not change with the turning of the year, steady as the stars above, but had we in December whispered of bicycles, or in January of cars, who can say how many more might have come to join us, how much brighter the logs might have burned against the winter’s night.

In the dusty halls of the Library of Congress, I wandered through the vaults of early Edison films, drawn to the flickering shadows of trick films that spanned the years from 1895 to 1901. Fifteen in number, these celluloid phantoms employed the sorcery of creative editing, weaving illusions that danced before the eye. My journey through this spectral archive was one of unraveling the poetics that lay hidden in the fabric of these films, tracing the thread of their evolution, and noting the peculiarities that marked the outliers of their kind. The trick films of that bygone era were shackled to the stage, their scenes framed within the confines of a frontal proscenium. The camera, steadfast and unmoving, captured long and medium shots, adhering to a rigid creed of one shot equaling one film. Yet, as the century turned, some dared to breach the established order, introducing the audacity of multiple shots.

What binds these trick films in common is their tether to an interior world, bound by the proscenium's embrace. The camera, like an unblinking sentinel, remains fixed, refusing to trail figures or objects beyond its ordained station. This composition, a vestige of theatre and the vaudevillian spectacle of magic acts, constrains the movement of figures to a horizontal dance, denying them the liberty to advance or retreat from the lens. Consider Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900), where actors slip in from the right, shuffling along the horizontal plane, vanishing beyond the frame as the camera holds its ground, indifferent to their departure.

In this proscenium-bound world, the shots stretch long, seldom breaking into medium. The intimacy of a close-up is a stranger here, for in the tradition of theatre and vaudeville, the audience beholds the entirety of the scene, bordered by the stage's edge. In the early days of film, actors remained distant, anchored in the middle ground, and the lens sought no intimacy with their visage.

These early trick films are bound by a singular notion: one conceptual shot for each film. This constraint clips their length to a minute or less, dictated by the flickering frames per second. The narrative scope is similarly curtailed, relegated to short bursts of vaudeville magic, disappearing acts, and sleight of hand, with scant regard for story. Yet, the viewer's eye may be deceived, for what seems a solitary shot may, in truth, be a tapestry of cuts, stitched together to conjure the illusion of apparitions. In The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895), scrutiny reveals the juncture where Mary's severed "head" appears, exposing the cunning artifice behind what is perceived as a single, seamless shot.

In the strange alchemy of words and time there exists a curious creature known as the Gothic novel, an odd confluence of old and new that Ian Watt in his musings named an oxymoron. This Gothic mode, much like the weathered stones of ancient castles, has endured the lashings of both disdain and praise. Its depths questioned and yet within its shadows lies the sublime terror that Burke spoke of. When Horace Walpole penned The Castle of Otranto, it was as if he grasped the ancient and the modern in his hand and forged a new path through the dark forests of literature. He took the old theater with its echoes and ghosts and the new mimicry of nature that novels had just begun to explore, and he wove them into what he called "A Gothic Story." This genre, with its nods to medieval theatre and architecture, to traditions long buried, stood as an anachronism even then. The very word "gothic" had wandered through history, applied to many peoples and styles, and was often seen as something archaic, a relic in the face of modernity. Yet it is this mingling of the theatrical and the novel’s intimate exploration of the human mind that allows the Gothic to linger, to be both ancient and novel to readers far removed from its inception.

There is a notion that runs deep through the Gothic, like a river beneath the earth, and that is the idea of chivalry. In the medieval times chivalry was the making of a knight, a process both sacred and severe, and it is in The Castle of Otranto that this ideal is both preserved and transformed. Gothic writers clung to this chivalric code, for it spoke of bravery and honor, of knights who stood as bastions of a decency they feared had vanished from the world. Walpole, caught in the maelstrom of political upheaval, looked to the past with a longing that bled into his writing. In those tales, the Gothic past became a romantic vision, a dream of what might mend the fractures of the present. Amidst the shadows of his own despair, he saw society as a thing unwound, its innate goodness gone astray. His characters, like Frederic, are painted with the hues of chivalry, though they walk in the twilight of Gothic excess. Frederic, a prince marred by tragedy and thought lost to the infidels, embodies the chivalric ideal. He stands as a figure of gallantry, exaggerated in his virtues, embodying the very excess that would become a hallmark of the Gothic. A knight caught between the echoes of the past and the creeping shadows of the new world.

In the vast machinery of commerce, there exists a flow unbroken, a great passage of goods from the moment a customer dreams a need to the time that need is met. This is the realm called supply chain management, a term first uttered in 1982 by one Keith Oliver, a man who saw the world as a map of connections yet to be drawn. He spoke of the planning and the controlling, a dance of elements all in service to the customer's fleeting desires. Six elements, he said. Production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and information. These are the bones of the enterprise, the sinews that draw the world closer.

Production is the first of those bones, the great foundation upon which all else is built. It is here the questions are asked: when and why, where and how. The managers, those stewards of industry, must discern the whispers of the market, that vast indicator of human wants. And when they have peered into the depths and understood, they decide what shall be born and how much. The place of its birth follows, a decision of plant and field, always with an eye to what the customer will bear. And when the place is known, they set to the work, scheduling and maintaining, for production is a fragile thing, a step in the chain that must be hewn with care. If it falters, the company may find itself adrift, time and money lost to the winds. I once walked the aisles of Wal-Mart and Target, places where every detail is a gospel, every process a script. The employee's garb, the trucks that bring the goods. All are known, all are ordered, so the company might move without falter, without doubt.

The second bone is supply, a thing of strategic choices. Here the manager must look to the facility, to the partners that might be drawn from the world beyond. A single product may be born in many places, each with its own tools and hands. The manager must choose wisely, decide where the task will best be done. Perhaps they will look to others, to the companies beyond, for in the end, it is velocity they seek. That balance of speed and quality, of cost kept low, a fine dance to satisfy the insatiable hunger of the market.

The novels of the Victorian age, with their intricate tapestries of detail and their homage to the nobility of their time, often stand as monuments to a world both richly adorned and rigidly ordered. Yet, within this era, there are tales like Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights that wander from the path, bearing a cloak of mystery and a taste for the peculiar that sets them apart. These stories delve into the shadowed corners of the human soul, where secrets dwell and the bizarre finds a home, crafting characters whose depths are laid bare in a dance of motives and emotion.

"And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, … he found that he was talking to them…. Suddenly he started back at the report of fire arms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which weared and tormented him incessantly." (Dickens, 220)

In these novels, the cloak of mystery often takes form through dreams or the haze of dreamlike states, each revealing its own truth. In Oliver Twist, such visions serve as a window into Oliver's soul, unveiling the shadows that torment him and his growing awareness of the grim realities that encircle him. When the echoes of gunfire revisit Oliver in the twenty-eighth chapter, the memory colors his mind with the vividness of a dream, casting him adrift in a struggle for salvation. The scene lays bare the absence of command he holds over his fate and reflects the frailty of his existence, the phantoms of Sikes and Crackit haunting his fevered mind. The gunshot reverberates through him, a cacophony of senses dulled, as he is swept away by invisible hands; his despair becomes a familiar companion, not born of sudden pain but a constant specter tethered to fear. Herein lies the question of whose hand guides his sorrow, for it is not his own. The shooting stands as testament to the helplessness that binds Oliver, an acceptance creeping into his soul, as if the sinister influence of old Fagin were etching its mark upon him, whispering despair into his ear, dulling his will to fight. For surely, if the spirit within him still burned bright, he would have grasped for some semblance of control, if only to preserve his own fragile life.

"The day passed off – day! There was no day; it was gone as soon as come – and night came on again; night so long, and yet so short; long in its dreadful silence and short in its fleeting hours."

In the years past, I found myself in the company of young minds at an after school program. These were children of elementary age, seeking guidance in the tangled thicket of their studies. I offered what aid I could, though my hand was surest in the realms of English and reading. It was there that I crossed paths with a young boy named Adrian, a lad of perhaps the third or fourth grade, who found himself wading through the murky waters of literacy. The peculiarities of his struggle were not lost on me. Some letters he grasped as if they were old friends, others eluded him entirely. It was the damnedest thing. He was of Latino descent, of this I was certain, yet the boy spoke the English tongue with the ease of any native. We wrestled with his troubles for a time, until providence saw fit to introduce me to his mother. On a day when I lingered with a few stragglers while their peers gallivanted on a field trip, she appeared. Her speech was of the Spanish variety, my own knowledge of which was patchwork at best. Yet in our stilted exchange, clarity emerged as though from a fog. Adrian's struggle was not with reading itself, but with the English alphabet, a revelation that struck me as if I'd been blindsided. Whether this insight served him in the end, I cannot say. But I hold hope that he fares better now.

This tale I recount is but a thread in the vast tapestry of the language barrier that looms over our schools, especially in the sun-drenched expanse of California. It stands as testament to the hidden nature of such obstacles. A child may speak English with the fluency of water over stone, yet reading it may prove a formidable mountain. We acknowledge the existence of this barrier, but what course do we chart to surmount it? For Adrian, the path was straightforward—tutoring in the basics of English reading, the alphabet, the sounds that comprise it. Yet for those children who find themselves adrift, scarcely speaking the language at all, the solution is a labyrinth. No singular remedy can bind this wound. The dual language system, mainstream immersion, private tutors, ESL instruction—none alone will suffice. The answer lies in a symphony of these approaches.

Consider first the dual language system, an idea ripe with promise. Not solely for those whose first breath was drawn in Spanish, but for all children. “Children in two-way bilingual education programs have been found to outshine their peers academically.” Fear clings to this notion, a specter of wasted resources, of the majority gaining naught. Yet such fears are unfounded. Were we to weave these programs into the fabric of every classroom, the benefits would be a shared bounty. How then do we proceed? Must we demand that all who teach be versed in two tongues? No, such a demand would be folly. But there is no reason we cannot enlist bilingual aides, tutors, those who can bridge the chasm.

From the time we are children most of us are told of that which lies beyond the compass of our understanding, a vastness in the world that dwarfs our small and flickering lives. Some are shepherded to Sunday school to seek it out, others find their way to Temple, or delve into the deep recesses of their own souls for answers. Many among us take up the mantle of faith passed down from our forebears, like old garments worn without question. But there are those who cast off such garments, defiant in their belief of a universe centered solely upon their own being. We might embrace one creed only to barter it for another in due time. Whatever path we tread upon, it is a journey to etch our own mark upon the stone of existence, to seek out a glimmer in the dark that might lead us from shadow into light.

"A cardinal," my father said when I asked about his favored bird. We sat on our porch as the rain drummed against the tin roof above, the smoke from our shared cigarettes curling into the moist air. The gutters spewed torrents that drowned the plants clinging to the porch's edge. He stared into the rain, eyes distant, caught between seeking and remembering. He had grown gaunt, clothes hanging slack from his frame, hair thinning to a sparse memory. His gaze stayed fixed on the rain, avoiding mine, and I sat there feeling alone and afraid, words unspoken between us about how much I would miss him, for to speak them would make them real. I hugged him then, and drew my chair closer, joining him in watching the rain fall in the dimming light of June's end.

He left this world in December, five days after I marked my twenty-second year. The chemo and radiation had done little but prolong his suffering past the bounds of what the doctors had foreseen; what worth lay in the extension of pain I could not fathom. I questioned then the nature of a God who might allow such things. Alone in the night, I found no prayers upon my lips. If God was, then He had turned His ear from me long ago.

I did not wish to see him pass from this life to whatever lay beyond. And so I did not. I could not bear to witness the ending of the life that had given me life. I wished to hold in memory the man as he had lived, not as he had died. Besides, I knew him better than they, better than kin or kith, and knew he would not want his child to watch as he slipped away. I lay curled in my bed for three days, awaiting the news.

But no word came.

In the quiet lands of Caroline, there walked a man named John Taylor, whose soul was bound to the soil and his heart to the creed of Republicanism. He was not merely a tiller of the land but a voice that rose above the furrows, speaking with fervor of liberty and governance. His life’s work in the earth and his fleeting dance with politics forged in him a steadfastness, a clarity in the discourse of freedom. The fields he tended became the bedrock of his beliefs, and from this ground, he cast his gaze upon the machinery of power, where he saw the virtue in an agrarian society. It was this vision that painted his views on sovereignty, on the Constitution, and even upon the courts of justice.

John Taylor beheld the new nation with eyes unclouded by ancient custom, seeing therein a canvas untouched, whereupon an ideal governance might be wrought. He was a stalwart believer in the natural rights of man, each a thread in the fabric of liberty, where to sever one was to fray them all and leave the whole diminished. These rights, he argued, must remain beyond the grasp of governance. He spoke of what some called the "state of nature," a realm where the strong and the cunning held sway, but within civilization, this must not hold.

To conjure forth this ideal realm, Taylor held that a government must reckon with the duality within man, a creature of both light and shadow. He was unyielding in his view of this moral dualism, declaring, "As government is exercised by man, all its virtues and vices must be human." He discerned good principles as those that shielded private property, nurtured the land, and cast a wary eye upon the rise of capital. Such a government, grounded in righteousness, would stand fair, its administration inevitably driven by greed and self-gain. Yet, he saw self-interest not as a sin, save when it birthed societies that thrived on the toil of others. A government of good must cage man's inherent darkness, ever watched lest it be twisted by ill principles.

Taylor, like the Republicans of his age, demanded the Constitution be held to its letter, its bounds tightly drawn around the Federal reach. He foresaw tyranny’s shadow in a sprawling Federal power and knew its cost was freedom. Yet he warned against a mere literal reading, for without the spirit of its makers, such interpretation could turn foul. More than this, he held the Declaration of Independence as the true charter, for it named the union as sovereign states bound together, not as one singular nation.

He stood there, eyes cast downward, the mind a barren plain. The view before him held in its silent embrace, dissected by that practiced scrutiny which sees but does not bind itself to the intangible. Thoughts drifted through like smoke on a wind, vanishing as soon as they formed. The workings of his mind so seamless they seemed not his own, but a flowing encounter with the scene laid bare before his eyes.

Once, there was an artist who spoke of a book. The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain, it was called, a guide to seeing and rendering the world anew. The book spoke of frames, of narrowing the vast to the simple, of reducing the cluttered tableau of the world—a bowl of fruit in a kitchen that opened to a dining room—to the mere essence of a bowl resting upon a plain. Yet here, in this moment, he could not summon such a frame. Overwhelmed, he stood captive to the sight, a witness to his own wonder. Picasso had his blues, Monet his greens, the Renaissance its kaleidoscope. And here, if his view were to claim the mantle of Art, would be his own magnum opus. The genesis of Work in Brown.

His fingertips found the chosen tool of his craft, muscles tensing and releasing as his hand traversed the air, intent made flesh in what could have been his most creative hour. The water swirled, serene as a mountain stream, clear as the morning light. Bits of matter broke free, swept away into oblivion. Muscles tightened anew, urgency flaring in the second attempt, as his hand struck the lever of the toilet once more. Yet the stubborn brown mass clung, unmoved, defiant as a rooted thing.

With mop in hand, feet set in their appointed stance, green tie knotted tight against his throat, he frowned at the insolent bundle of waste left behind by some heedless soul. A few more flushes, a few moments' meditative quiet, then his hand reached for the paper on the wall, wrapping itself until it wore the guise of a baker's mitt. Straightening, then bending, his hand dipped into the bowl, slow and deliberate, like a mother reaching into the oven for Thanksgiving's feast.

In the dry and sunbaked stretches of highway, where the horizons are endless and the road winds like a serpent through the desolate land, young souls are claimed by the asphalt. A convergence of misfortune and folly marks the path of the youngest who steer these machines of steel and glass. The National Institutes of Health speaks of the unripe mind, a mind not yet honed to the perils that crouch in the shadows of driving. And it is this lack of weathered experience that lies coiled at the heart of their misfortune. It breeds not only ruinous wrecks but sends them hurtling off the road, overturning their vessels, and hurtling into the void.

When they ride with their ilk, the folly compounds. A truth known to any who have crossed paths with the young and reckless. The Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center has laid bare a grim equation: the age of the passenger and the tally of calamities incurred.

In lands like California, they have sought to weave a net of safety for these fledgling drivers with provisional licenses that bind them to the hours and the company they keep. Yet these measures, in my reckoning, are but patches on a wound that bleeds. For the youngest, by all accounts, are not yet steeled to the demands thrust upon them. Marvin Zuckerman, a man of study into the mind's wild inclinations, believes even eighteen summers is too few for such a burden. USA Today echoes his findings, the young driven by a lust for the sensation of risk. Better, then, to stay their hands from the wheel till the fire within cools to embers.

Should we persist in granting leave to the young to roam the roads, the tally of the fallen will rise to a grievous height. The children of the Baby Boomers stand at the ready, millions poised to take the wheel. The year 2010 will see a tide of young drivers loosed upon the thoroughfares.

To address this, the path is clear. Let the schools sow the seeds of knowledge for those who will one day drive, yet hold the keys from hands under eighteen. Let provisional permits be given, with training cut from the cloth of the state's requirements—California asks six hours behind the wheel and fifty in practice.

The grim statistics do not heed borders. Thus, a law drawn across the nation, uniform and unwavering, could be the shield we need for our youth. This notion is not new, but in the light of what looms, it is a course both wise and just.

In the vast and silent corridors of the mind where sound should find its meaning, there lies a disorder known as Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD. It is a specter that shadows the pathways of the brain, where the central nervous system wrestles with the whispers of the world, unable to decipher them as it should. In this paper, we tread through three territories of this enigmatic condition. We begin with a definition that seeks to capture its elusive nature. We then delve into the realm of diagnosis, marking the telltale signs that betray its presence. Finally, we journey to the classroom, where a teacher stands as a beacon for those students adrift in the sea of sound.

The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, in one of its many reckonings, described CAPD as the efficiency and effectiveness by which the central nervous system employs auditory information. A disorder not of the ears but of the mind's translation, where the common sounds of life become a cacophony without a guide. These individuals hear the world as it is, yet the compass of their mind falters, unable to distinguish the vital from the trivial, the spoken word from the ambient noise.

Its origins trace back to the mid-1950s, a time when the disorder was but a whisper called "auditory imperception." Researchers, like the Italian team of Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari, began their quest in 1954, seeking to illuminate the shadows cast by communicative disorders in children. By 1961, Kimura introduced dichotic testing, a novel attempt to map the uncharted territories of the auditory pathways. In 1977, a gathering of minds further fanned the flames of inquiry into the lives of children burdened by CAPD.

The manifestations of CAPD are as varied as they are subtle. Those afflicted may wander through a soundscape with no landmarks, unable to locate or discern sound amidst the din. They may struggle to separate the sounds of life, to hear the music in the noise, the words in the wind. Their world may lack the harmony of recognition, the melody of change, the rhythm of sequence. The disorder blocks and distorts, leaving them adrift in a sea of sounds that refuse to coalesce into meaning.

To diagnose CAPD is to embark on a quest through the labyrinth of sound. It requires the keen eyes and ears of audiologists, speech-language pathologists, psychologists, and others who wield their tools and tests like explorers mapping unknown lands. Questionnaires and observations are their compasses, guiding them through the auditory behaviors of the patient. Yet, as of now, no single tool can claim victory over the disorder, no singular cause has been unearthed. The tests, varied and complex, present the patient with a symphony of stimuli, seeking to tease out the patterns hidden within. More advanced measures delve deeper, recording the echoes within the ear, measuring the mind's response to this unseen symphony.

In the pursuit of knowledge and a path unformed, I find myself drawn towards the realm of social work with the Division of Family and Children Services. There, I seek to mend the lives of children scarred by abuse or neglect and to offer solace to families lost in turmoil. The values I carry into this calling are not mere principles of the trade but are etched into my very being—service, respect, a moral compass unwavering, a dedication to bridge the chasms between souls, and a vow to hone my craft so as never to falter in my duty. These are not just tenets of a social worker; they are the cornerstones of my life.

From the days of my youth, the urge to lend aid was a constant whisper, yet the road ahead lay shrouded in mist. In the halls of my schooling, both high and higher, I watched as many turned their backs on their shadows, and some clung to crutches unworthy of their weight. It was in these moments, these glimpses into the struggles of others, that I chose a path towards a Bachelor's in Psychology. Still, the destination eluded me, and so after my time at Piedmont College came to its natural end in 2009, I paused. That summer, a chance encounter with a boy of sixteen, perched uneasily on a friend's couch, set my course. Fleeing from the tyranny of his own blood, he had sought refuge. On the morrow, the law was summoned to his kin's abode, and I followed, driven by an instinct to intervene. The officers, finding their hands bound by the letter of the law, bid me speak with the boy's parents, and I did. Their words were cloaked in nervousness and feeble excuses, painting their son's cries for help as mere manipulations. In that moment, the notion of social work grew roots within me, a resolve to aid those ensnared by the so-called "simple" disputes of kinship.

Justice, too, beats at the heart of this vocation. In our society, we speak of the sanctity of the individual, yet our lamentations for the lost ring hollow, echoing traditions long past. If we truly mourn those who have departed, why then do we strive to mold ourselves in the likeness of others? I stand apart, unyielding, unwilling to don the chains of conformity. Through the years of my education, I railed against the injustices I encountered, be it through the colors in my hair, the fabric that clothed me, the piercings that adorned my skin, or my voice raised in alliance with those who dared to love freely. Against racism and discrimination, I have stood firm, and I shall continue to do so, for social justice is a cause I carry like a torch against the encroaching dark.

In the dim corridors of human understanding, there lies the study of sleep and its many troubles. Insomnia, that persistent thief of rest, finds itself examined through the lenses of both biology and the tangled web of sociocultural influences. The biological path winds through the genetic landscapes, where the shadows of inheritance and the cold, clinical truths of medicine dwell. Meanwhile, the sociocultural path meanders through the interactions of environment, the unyielding constructs of race and class, and the burdens of demographic circumstance. This paper seeks to illuminate these paths, drawing upon the flickering candlelight of research to guide the way. Each study, like a stone in a riverbed, is turned over to reveal both its polished strengths and its hidden flaws.

In the realm of sleep's disorders, they are marked by primary afflictions or as symptoms tethered to deeper mental disturbances, or perhaps as shadows cast by other maladies. Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, these are the names given to nightmares and waking terrors that haunt the night. Primary Insomnia, a restless foe that denies the comfort of sleep, stands opposed to Primary Hypersomnia, where wakefulness is a distant shore. Narcolepsy, with its sudden descents into dream, and the rhythm of circadian disarray, all find their places in this litany of sleep's disorders. Parasomnias, with their spectral behaviors and strange physiological tales, recount nightmares and sleepwalks that traverse the boundaries of the conscious and unconscious. 

The whisperings of the biological model speak of neurons and chemical messengers, the language of genes and heritable shadows. In the hypothalamus, where orexin neurons hold court, the balance of sleep and wakefulness is struck. Studies with mice, those silent witnesses to human inquiry, reveal the presence of GABAB receptors on these neurons, guardians of sleep states. The GABAA receptor, when stirred to life, calls forth the balm of sleep, while its silence begets restlessness. Such findings, though born in the minds of mice, suggest truths that may echo in the human form. 

Yet, the sociocultural voice cannot be stilled. It murmurs of inherited phenotypes and the societal weights that press upon the individual. Should the receptors fail, the disturbance ripples outward, unsettling the delicate balance of life's pursuits. The classroom, the workplace, those spaces of mundane focus, all threatened by the restless nights. Thus, the disorder of insomnia is not merely a biological aberration but a reflection of the broader human condition, a testament to the intricate dance of genes and society.

I have wandered these grounds at University Park for some two and a half years now. The semesters, four and a half in their passage. The campus sprawls wide and the journey across it is a trial for many, myself tangled among them. In the first year of my stay they placed me in a dorm by East Halls, near as far east as the campus will let you wander unless you count the vastness of the stadium and the Bryce Jordan Center. From Stuart Hall, my abode, to the distant halls of Willard, situated near the heart of this academic sprawl, could take up to twenty-five minutes by foot, longer if the skies turned foul as they often do in State College. An alum, not much older than myself, spoke of a time not long past when East Halls sat bordered by vast, empty lands. Now those tracts are filled with sports fields and looming edifices, the new Creamery and the health services building rising among them, hemmed in by apartments. As the campus stretches ever outward, the passage from one corner to another grows more arduous. And what remedy might there be for such a plight? On these grounds, it is the bicycle that holds promise. Yet a bike alone is no panacea. Students must take to them, and the campus must bend to their needs.  
A friend of mine, who took up cycling again after years adrift, spoke of his wonder at why he ever left it. "Bikes are great," he said, "for a time it seemed folly to ride, but it’s the only way to get around." Not only does it serve the body well, but bicycling stands as the most efficient means of travel. A bowl of oats and a bit of muscle will carry you thirty miles or more. Like many of my peers, I dwell off campus now, as distant from the heart of things as some dorms might be. This year, the wisest move I've made was to acquire a bike. Each day I must reach the Thomas building, a good twenty-five-minute walk from my door if by foot alone. With the bike, the time shrinks to a scant five minutes, provided I ride with purpose. Yet Pollock Road, the most direct path to Thomas, is not always an easy way, bike or no. There is merit in walking too, but I find my days too filled to afford it. Without my bike, walking would be my sole recourse to reach class. Such a trek to Thomas each day would steal an extra thirty to forty minutes from my hours. That's over two and a half hours lost to the week. And when you tally the time spent on foot to other classes and meetings and such, it becomes a cost too dear to pay.

In the shadowed corridors of Huxley’s Brave New World, there lies a world both strange and familiar, where the faces of men and women are but reflections in a glass darkly. A world where the hum of machines and the whispers of commerce form a haunting litany, binding all who dwell there in a dance of hollow joy. It is a place where the soul of man is woven into the great loom of technology and capitalism, and in its weaving, finds itself undone. These folk, these denizens of a new epoch, are cradled from birth in the arms of a manufactured happiness, a balm for the spirit that seeks no deeper truth than the surface of things. 

Here, the game is played on a vast board, the pieces moved by unseen hands, the World Controller the architect of destinies not their own. The specter of Marx watches over this tableau, for in its unfolding, there is laid bare the suspicion of systems, the uneasy dream of progress. Terms of art, words like homogeny and reification, whisper of a time when the soul of man was not yet sold to the highest bidder, when the heart sought more than the promise of a new thing. 

The satire is sharp, the critique unyielding. False consciousness, the mask worn by the multitudes, is the child of capitalism’s embrace. The people, tethered to their desires, are blind to the chains that bind them. Their world is one of consumption, of endless want, and in hypnopædia's lullaby, they find their singular truth. The World Controller, the puppet master, ensures that the dance continues, that hegemony remains unchallenged. The lower castes, Delta and Gamma, move through life unaware, ensnared in a web they cannot see, their thoughts not their own. 

Even the Alphas and Betas live in the shadow of the machine, their awareness a burden they do not wish to carry. Bernard, one among few, glimpses the strings, but even he finds himself swept along in the current. In this world, the social order is a mirror, reflecting the iron grip of capitalism, the silent hand that shapes all things. 

There is no love here, no true bond between souls, only the echo of what once was. Huxley paints his characters as if they are but phantoms, their depths unexplored, for perhaps in this, he speaks of a truth—that the rise of machine and market has stripped away the essence of man. The heart’s desires are but shadows, fleeting and insubstantial. Men speak of women as objects, their words devoid of warmth or connection, and the women, in turn, speak boldly of encounters as if they were transactions, devoid of feeling. 

The classes are content, blind to the bars of their gilded cage, their obedience a testament to the power of the unseen hand. The proletariat, in their consuming, are bound to the wheel, deceived into believing they are more than they are. In their complacency, we see the mark of Marx’s thought, the echo of a warning unheeded, as they move through their days in a dance of obedience, never questioning, never straying from the path laid before them.

It was near four years gone now that I found myself enrolled in a course on Islam at the college. And there in the modest room with its linoleum floor and wooden desks, we argued the nature of the religion, whether it was hostile and its intentions dark, or if there was another truth to be seen. I reckon the question has only grown more pertinent with time's passage. Since the day the towers fell, I've watched the media's stance shift from one of open hostility toward Islam and its extremists, to a more bewildering tolerance. I’d wager that back in 2001, the notion of a man named Barack Obama, with ties to the Muslim faith, standing as a candidate for the presidency would have seemed far-fetched.

The life of the Prophet, as I’ve come to know it, is a tale that fascinates me for its contradictions. The history of Muhammad, as I understood it, painted him as a conqueror, one who bent tribes to his will and demanded their submission to Islam. Yet the biography speaks of a martyr, misunderstood, humble in his dealings. People, so it is written, came to him of their own accord, drawn to the truth he preached.

There’s a curious likeness in the ministries of Jesus and the fabled acts of Muhammad. The most striking is the tale of the multiplication of mutton and milk to feed forty men. Such narratives lead me to suspect the writers intended to cast Muhammad in a light akin to a humble prophet, whose truth and miracles needed no defense. This, to my thinking, undermines the unique wonder of Christ’s life, as if they were pilfering the essence of Jesus to bolster Muhammad.

The biography is replete with accounts that aim to show how folks, seemingly unbidden, found their way to Islam. Yet these tales often come from second or third-hand sources, hearsay and whispers. The intention, I reckon, was to lend authenticity, but it only served to sow doubt, rendering the stories suspect in my eyes.

What troubles me most is the portrayal of Muhammad as a paragon of humility, wisdom, and gentleness. History paints a starkly different picture, one not of gentleness but of power and conquest. And I can't help but wonder if those who follow Islam today are aware of the true history that shadows the Prophet’s ascent.

In the dusty annals of time, where the echoes of ancient footsteps still whisper, there lies the tale of a man whose teachings were like seeds scattered upon the earth, only to be left behind by the hands that tilled the fields of thought thereafter. The man, Jesus, spoke of truths in a world now shadowed by its own interpretations, and as the years have unfurled, the path of Christianity has wandered far from its source. In the broad sweep of history, a pattern emerges—a journey away from beginnings, a divergence carried by the winds of time. Yet in the present age, there stirs an awakening, a burgeoning consciousness that tugs at the roots of what has been sown. The world, as it stands, bears witness to a shift, a swell of progress that seeks to unravel the tapestry back to its original threads.

In this landscape of change, there are those who cling to the old ways, steadfast in their inheritance. They form a bulwark, a resistance, but their numbers may falter against the tide of history. Among the faithful, an awareness blooms, a thirst to discern the essence of the faith from the accretions of doctrine amassed over epochs. This quest for purity may span decades, perhaps centuries, but its course seems set—the wheel of Christian history poised to turn back upon itself. A great movement shall rise, a tide that peels away the layers of time, as if reversing the very flow of the hourglass, until what remains is a vision of what once was, a return to the simplicity of a carpenter's voice echoing in the hills of Galilee.

This tide shall sweep through lands, from the heartlands of America to the old world of Europe, drawing the multitudes to a form of worship stripped of all but the essence. The church, a bastion upon the shifting sands, shall guide this return, yet with the reversal of the theological clock shall come a convergence, a harmony in belief and practice that erodes the divisions long held sacred. Where once there were chasms, there shall be bridges; where once there were countless voices, a singular song. History is a river marked by such reversions, and the chronicles of man are filled with them. Recall the days when the Roman Empire, mighty and unyielding, sought to quench the flame of Christianity, only to be consumed by it in turn. The passage from chains to leadership in the American saga tells of a similar arc.

The reversion that looms upon the horizon of faith will see history undone, a search for the source, a dissolution of diversity into unity. Central to this unfolding shall be a reading of Jesus’ words, not as rigid proclamations, but as metaphors, keys to unlock deeper truths. Thus, the question remains—what path has led us here, since the days when Jesus walked among us? 

Look back, far into the shadows of antiquity, and there stands Judaism, the bedrock upon which the edifice of Christianity was raised. Monotheism, the revelation divine, the authority of Hebrew scripture—these were the pillars when Rome took Jerusalem beneath its banner in 63 B.C.E. Yet even then, the Jewish soul was not singular. It fractured into Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the multitude of the common folk, each with their own vision, their own truth.

In the world Sinclair lays bare, there is a darkness in the human heart that speaks to greed as a natural law. The Jungle unfurls this truth with the relentless precision of a knife. Men scrabble through the bones of their own kind, seeking out the gold in marrow, eyes fixed only on their own horizon. The owners and masters of the roaring factories, these titans of industry, they are blind in their ambition. They see not the blood and smoke that rises to the heavens nor care for the souls crushed beneath their iron wheels. Sinclair writes of the monolithic structures, their silhouettes harsh against the sky, the smoke trailing to the world's edge. A testament to the cold heart of progress. He whispers of the filth that flows unchecked from the pens, a silent flood of waste that drowns the land.

In those days, the worth of a man was measured in dollars and cents, and a dollar he was not. "A cauldron of jealousies and hatreds," Sinclair calls it, a place where no shred of loyalty or decency remains. Men toil under the yoke of greed, hours stretching into the dim hours of night, only to be cast aside like husks without notice or recompense. Laws to shield them were scarce as water in a drought, leaving the workers to fend off the wolves alone, the managers urging them to the brink of ruin. The silence of suffering is deafening, the expectation that they endure the unendurable, the unsaid truth of their existence. No hand reaches out to lift them from their plight, no agency or soul to guide them through the wreckage. Unions rise and fall like dust, feeding off the laborers as surely as their masters. They are slaves in all but name, described by Sinclair as a people on the edge of starvation, bound to the whims of men as cruel as any slave driver of old. Immorality blooms in such soil, inevitable as weeds in an untended field.

In the dim corridors of literature, where shadows linger and words echo, Edgar Allan Poe's "Dream-Land" stands as a testament to the depths of man's imagination. Poe, in his craft, invokes the ancient term “Thulé,” a relic of Virgil's musings, a whisper of lands beyond known maps, where the Greeks once dreamed the world might end. Virgil's invocation of Thulé clings to the edges of history, and yet, in Poe's hands, it finds new life, perhaps spurred by his fascination with the Germanic soul, the echoes of Goethe.

In this dance of words, Karl J. Arndt, a scholar of old, draws a line between Poe and Goethe, suggesting the former's mimicry of the latter, as if one shadow were cast by another. Goethe, a giant of letters, left the world his Faust, a tale in two acts, the first breathing life in 1808 and the second released as he himself returned to the earth in 1832. Nestled within Faust's verses lies “The King of Thulé,” a mournful tale of a king bereft, his queen gone to dust, her memory etched in a goblet, a testament to loss and the slow poison of remembrance. The king, now adrift, surrenders his worldly goods, save the goblet, which he flings into the abyss of the sea before surrendering to his own fate.

The air of Thulé, dark and foreboding, mirrors the landscapes of Poe's "Dream-Land," where specters of dead companions haunt the speaker, and the world's colors fade to a shadowed gray. The King of Thulé, in his drink and despair, is perhaps a reflection of Poe's own demons, a dark twin of grief and the solace found in the bottle. It is no wonder that less than a year before Poe penned "The Pit and the Pendulum," the term Thulé seeped into his consciousness, a thread connecting him to the romantic dramas that swept the stage in the wake of Goethe's shadow.

In the storied passages of Poe's collected works, Thulé emerges, first in "The Pit and the Pendulum" as “ultima Thule,” and then twice in "Dream-Land," bookending the poem like a silent sentinel. The words draw the pieces together, a dialogue across time with Goethe's "The King of Thulé." The landscapes of both are heavy with solitude and loss, as if the speaker in "Dream-Land" has wandered into Goethe's lament, a spectral journey through the ruin of memory.

Goethe, a pillar of the literary world, would have been a presence in Poe's mind, if for no other reason than the respect he bore for Tennyson. In the weave of words, Poe's path crosses with Goethe, through the echoes of their shared respect for the poet laureate, and in the manifold translations and adaptations that Goethe's works inspired. Thus, in the quiet spaces between lines, one finds the soul of Poe, reaching back to touch the hand of Goethe, through the veil of Thulé.

In the land of California, where the sun beats down upon the fields and the law holds sway like an ancient scripture, there arose a question of justice. Could a soul, battered and bruised from a fall upon spilled applesauce in a store, seek the cold comfort of punitive recompense by claiming the keeper of the store harbored malice in his heart? This keeper, twice informed of the slick danger, yet chose his meal over duty's call for a full thirty minutes. 

The judge, he sits there in his black robes, not likely to cast aside Jennifer Palmer's plea for punitive measures without due consideration. She must show the court that the storekeeper's deeds were not just negligent, but born of a willful disregard for the harm that might ensue, that his conduct was vile in its indifference. Palmer will lay before them the tale of Martin, who should have known better, for in the months before her own mishap, others had danced unbidden upon similar spills, their cries echoing in the aisles. Yet Martin, with eyes wide open to the chaos, chose inaction. Her claim of his despicable nature might ring weaker, yet it gains strength from the stores of history, six times in the year of our Lord two thousand and nine had bones met the hard floor and Martin remained unmoved.

On a day in October, the thirteenth of the month at the hour when the sun begins its descent, Rich Wayne, a servant of D&D Markets, came to Martin with news of the applesauce peril. Martin, seated at his table, dismissed the warning, preferring the solace of his meal. Fifteen minutes passed and another, Mary J. Haddigan, sounded the alarm anew, only to be met with the same disdain. And so it was at that time, half past the hour, that Palmer found herself upon the floor, her back bearing the brunt of Martin's negligence. Five times before had the store seen such calamity that year alone. And now Palmer seeks both compensation for her pain and punishment for the neglect that led her there, while they deliberate on whether to pursue a motion against her claim for punitive damages.

In the eyes of Californian law, one may grasp at punitive damages not born of contract if the transgressor acted with the shadows of oppression, deceit, or malice. The code speaks of malice as a deed intended to wound or, if not intended, so loathsome in its execution that it was done with a knowing and willful neglect of the safety owed to others. The courts have seen malice in the actions of those who, knowing the peril their deeds might unleash, chose not to avert the storm. Thus, the tale unfolds, and the law and the land await what justice will decree.

She had always been haunted by a sense of wanting, a hollow yearning that refused to be sated, a ghost of desire that whispered in the shadows of her being. It had begun when she was fourteen, a tender age when the world first began to reveal its vastness and its mysteries, and it lingered still three years hence at seventeen. By then, she knew it was someone she sought, not something, yet no boy had caught her eye. Suitors had come and gone, awkward rituals of courtship unfurling like some ancient dance, but her heart remained unmoved. She questioned this peculiar state, pondering what might cause such a deviation from the expected path of a young girl's heart. The years spun out theories in her mind like gossamer threads, none substantial enough to unravel her enigma. So she drifted through life, her desires a riddle murmuring in her soul.

The days at home were serene, a stillness that wrapped around her like a quilt. Her parents were gentle folk, their voices never raised in anger, and disputes with their daughter were rare as rain in a desert. Their only quarrel lay in her fierce independence, a fire that flared bright against their calm. She was a daughter who danced to her own tune, a burst of color in the quiet tapestry of their lives, her vibrancy a magnet for others drawn to her light.

But today the peace shattered like glass. As she wandered from room to room, seeking some spark to ignite her own restless spirit, a scream knifed through the stillness—a sharp note from her mother’s voice. She flew to the kitchen, panic rising like a tide within her. "Mom?! Mom, what's the matter?!" Her mother lay prone on the floor, pain etched into every line of her face, breath coming in short, pained gasps. "Ow," she whispered, "swee... ty, I... need you to take me... to the hospital." The words were squeezed from her, each a testament to her agony. "Okay Mom, just tell me what to do." Her mother pointed, and in that moment, the daughter was grateful for the strength she had honed. She lifted her mother, bore her to the car, and laid her gently in the back, then drove with a heart pounding with urgency.

The hospital loomed, a fortress of sterility and fear, its air thick with the scent of antiseptic and unspoken dread. But she did not smell it, her mind consumed by the singular task of aiding her mother. She carried her inside, her voice a beacon calling for aid. Faces gathered, concern etched into their features. A rolling bed appeared, and they laid her mother upon it, whisking her away into the labyrinth of care. The daughter was left behind, a solitary sentinel in a waiting room of worry.

Her mother had fallen from a stepping stool, reaching for a vase perched high upon a cabinet, a simple act that had spiraled into calamity.

In the vast annals of human inquiry, this study was wrought from the necessity to discern the bond between adherence to what the ancients called the Mediterranean Diet and the specter of chronic heart disease and the grim reaper known as stroke. The diet, in its alternate form, the aMed diet, stands as a testament to simplicity and the earth’s bounty. It whispers of fruits and nuts, whole grains, legumes, and the oils of olives, favoring the unsaturated over the bloated excesses of animal fats, allowing for the gentle indulgence of the vine's nectar.

In the chronicles of science past, there have been whispers, threads of evidence woven into tales of this diet’s power over the heart's maladies and the relentless march of mortality. Its superiority over the austere confines of a low-fat regimen was noted, a harbinger of weight shed and the blood’s chemistry altered. Yet, in these tales, the dire strokes of fate were oft left in shadow.

The saga unfolds with seventy-four thousand eight hundred and eighty-six women, nurses by trade, from the tender age of thirty-eight to the cusp of sixty-three. They, unmarked by the histories of cardiovascular affliction or diabetes, stood as sentinels in this study, woven into the fabric of the Nurses' Health Study that spanned eleven states. From the year of our Lord nineteen hundred and eighty-four to two thousand and four, their dietary tales were recorded sixfold through the self-reported food frequency questionnaires. The steadfastness of these women was near absolute, with over ninety-five percent holding true to the course across two decades. Their reports of heart and stroke were etched in the stone of medical records and autopsies, or when absent, deemed probable, casting a shadow on a small fraction of strokes and heart events.

To grasp the truth of their diet, the scores were culled from years past, smoothing the randomness of a single year’s consumption. Age and smoke, the weight of their bodies, the state of their hormones, all were accounted for, lest they cloud the findings. The hand of Cox modeling was employed, sifting through the sands of data to reveal the link between diet and the fates of heart and stroke, each in their fatal and nonfatal guises.

The reckoning was clear. Those women who embraced the diet of the Mediterranean, who stood atop the quintile, found themselves less likely to fall to the ravages of heart and stroke than those who lingered at the base, their risk reduced by a measure of 0.71. Such was the tale told by the study over the long years, a testament to the diet’s power against the silent killers of the heart and brain.

The sign says Hitler lives in Burma.  
Ellen Page, known for her role in Juno, stands alone on a street corner. Her arm raised high, clutching a piece of cardboard with those words scrawled in dark Sharpie, a message bleak and unsettling. Burma, or Myanmar, lies in the heart of Southeast Asia, ruled by a harsh military junta whose grip tightened in 1962 when power was seized in a coup d'état. In 2007, the streets bore witness to protests not seen in a decade, led by the holy men clad in saffron robes, the monks. The Saffron Revolution, they called it, named for the hue of the robes that draped the monks, those bearers of peace in a land shrouded in tyranny. At first the junta watched with reluctance as the monks assembled peacefully, but soon the tide turned. Violence surged and the streets became a battleground, monasteries desecrated by the hands of soldiers. Foreign eyes that dared to capture truth were snatched, imprisoned. Kenji Nagai, a Japanese photojournalist, fell on September 27, 2007—his only crime, witnessing the streets' unrest. The official count said thirteen lost souls, but Colonel Hla Win, a man who fled the army's ranks, spoke of more, a multitude silenced, bodies numbering in the thousands.

Yet this is no new tale. History is a scroll of blood and power, of rulers who stifle the breath of dissent to clutch their dominion. The emperors of Rome, claiming divine favor, wielded absolute power over their domains. In Japan, emperors walked as gods among men, leading their people into modernity and death alike. Our own president, George W. Bush, converses weekly with Ted Haggard, a shepherd of the unenlightened flock, under the aegis of the Republic Party.

The pages of history are marked by such tyranny. The 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, where scholars and laborers and youth stood against the iron rule of governance, tell of a massacre veiled by numbers that shift like sand, from the government's two or three hundred to the thousands whispered by the Chinese Red Cross. Rwanda in the nineties, its soil soaked with the blood of Tutsis and moderates alike, slaughtered by Hutu militias with the government's nod. And then there was the Third Reich, Hitler's reign, a dark age when Jewish lives were extinguished across nations.

In the long shadows cast by the night, a man sits at a piano, fingers tracing the keys as if they were the lines of a well-worn map. His name is Duke Ellington, a name that carries with it the weight of years and the echoes of a hundred thousand notes. His legacy in the world of jazz is woven not merely from time but from the threads of creation, an orchestra shaped by his hand and mind. The piano, his silent companion, whispers its presence in the compositions that dance like phantoms across the worn paper, each one a testament to Ellington’s genius. As a composer, he built worlds within worlds, crafting pieces of such intricate beauty that the band members found their true voices within his frames.

Ellington’s genius lay in the way he understood the soul of his orchestra, each player a solitary note in a grand symphony. He forged spaces where the soloist could soar, untethered, while simultaneously crafting phrases that bound the ensemble in a tapestry of sound, each thread a reflection of his vision. In this alchemy, he found the soul of his music, a coherent sound that was uniquely his own. His mastery was not just of the notes but of the men who played them, and in that mastery, he wrote his name across the annals of jazz history.

Among the pages of the Grove Music dictionary, there are whisperings of Ellington’s sound, a sound that found voice in the piece known as Creole Love Call. Here, the voice becomes not a vessel of words, but an instrument, pure and unadorned. This was Ellington’s way, weaving texture and color into the silence, a testament to his skill in complementing the voices of his soloists. The slow cadence of a twelve-bar blues unfolds, each chorus a chapter in a story without words:

The first chorus, a conversation between voice and reeds, begins softly, a gentle melody that grows rougher, more insistent. The muted trumpet follows, exploring the melody’s shadows, bending notes to its will. A clarinet rises, sweeping high above the earth, underpinned by the subtle syncopation of the piano. The full band swells, echoing the first chorus, brass and reeds locked in a call and response. As the fifth chorus builds, the reeds take the lead, their voices high and clear, the rhythm section marking time in syncopated stops. And the final chorus returns to the beginning, the voice growling as an instrument, echoing the dialogue with the reeds. A brief tag closes the piece, a vocal run ending in the dissonant sigh of a trombone.

Ellington’s voice, his true instrument, lies in the way he colors a piece, each note a brushstroke in a masterwork. In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year hence, his skill at orchestration melds with his ear for tone. ‘Bubber’ Miley’s muted trumpet converses with Baby Cox’s scat singing, each voice a reflection of the other, creating a sound both rich and strange. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) takes these ideas further, Ellington’s hand guiding Joe ‘Tricky Sam’ Nanton’s muted trombone to introduce the melody, a touchstone in the vast landscape of Ellington’s creation.

In the quiet calculus of life, why do creatures change their form as they do? What hidden hands bid them to evolve along certain paths and not others? It's a question pondered by men given to deeper thoughts than most, like D'Arcy Thompson, who mused upon the mathematical nature of life’s simplest forms, way back in the year 1917. And even now, the riddle remains unsolved. Yet, with the passage of years, minds like Raup and Stanley turned their gaze to the humble mollusk, seeking patterns in the spiral dance of shells across the ages.

Our inquiry ventures into the realm of hard numbers and soft forms, where we study the genus Prunum through the twin lenses of mathematics and experiment. We harness the power of X-rays to capture the ghostly outlines of shells, parsing them into figures and formulas that might unlock the secrets of evolutionary change. Into the computer’s maw we feed these numbers, using a tool born of the modern age, CerioShell, to conjure forth visions of shells that might have been. These visions help us chart the borders of possibility, the land where change is born.

Consider a shell, not merely as nature’s ornament, but as a tale writ in stone, a tube spun slowly through the vastness of time. Each revolution, each whirl around its hidden axis—the columella—is a chapter in its story. The pace of its growth, the lines of its past, these sutures, they whisper of its journey. At its heart is the body whorl, last and largest, while the spire rises, apex to base, as if reaching for the heavens. Life within reaches out through the aperture, the portal to its world.

In contemplation, these shells reveal themselves from every angle—apical, basal, apertural, and abapertural—as if inviting understanding from every perspective. The common view, aperture forward, apex skyward, speaks most clearly to us.

To count the whorls is to trace the labyrinthine path of life itself. Begin at the shell’s peak, mark the start of its first suture, and divide its form with an unseen line. From here, the whorls count themselves, each a testament to a quarter turn more of life’s relentless march.

View the shell as a procession of apertures, a dance through space and time, as the creature within builds its spiraled home. By plotting the center of each whorl’s aperture, by charting the radius both wide and high, we map this journey.

And in this mapping, in these symbols and signs, lies the power to alter the course of skeletogenesis, to walk the path of gods and change the fate of mollusks. We turn the unknown into known, the unseen into seen, through the lens of mathematics that seeks to comprehend the very essence of life’s unfolding.

In the quiet lands of Indonesia, where the sun casts long shadows upon the earth, the toll of newborns and infants taken too soon has held its ground against the passage of a decade. Though the nation strides with purpose toward the Millennium Development Goals, like a traveler on a well-trodden path to fresh waters and purified air, the hopes for the health of mothers and their children remain distant, like a mirage in the desert sands. These aspirations, unmet, speak of a need not for mere remedies but for the fortification of the very foundations of their healing ways.

In the villages and towns, they have seen the hands of skilled healers at the birthside grow more frequent, now at seventy-two in every hundred, yet among these are those whose craft is of the old ways, the midwives, whose gentle guidance cannot stave off the crimson tide should it rise. Thus, the numbers, though they tell a tale of progress, do whisper deceitfully of a journey far from its end. The children who suffer the scourge of diarrhea find fewer hands of trained healers to comfort them, and in the days after birth, the care that should cradle mother and child falters, a flickering candle in the wind.

In the realm of childbirth, the knife that might save a life is seldom wielded, with cuts made in only four of every hundred. In the bustling heart of the cities, these cuts are sevenfold, yet in the quiet stretches of the countryside, they dwindle to two. It is a stark telling of a land divided by access, where the healing touch gathers in cities and leaves the rural folk to fend with less. Among the rich and the poor, a chasm of twenty-seven in a hundred stands, a testament to the hardships faced by those with less, their way barred by the weight of coin.

And so, the road ahead lies obscured by questions. How shall they breathe life into the care for mother and child? Should they seek the allure of singular paths, or should they bind their strength to the shaping of a robust system, one that does not forsake those at the start and end of life’s journey? The call of focused endeavors, like the siren’s song, is tempting, promising swift victories with clear goals. Yet, heed must be given to the shadows they cast, for a heavy hand upon one part may drain the lifeblood from another, drawing away the healers to where the riches flow. Parallel tracks in the sand, uncoordinated and redundant, lead only to a tangle of forms, a labyrinth of papers and pleas.

Thus, the story unfolds, and the choices lie before them like roads diverging in a quiet wood, each with its promise and peril. The way must be chosen with care, for upon it rests the hope of many, the silent prayer for a brighter dawn.

In the slow turning of a century past, the landscape of what folks call Popular Music has grown wild and tangled, a bramble of genres blooming in every direction, so that to name them all is a task near impossible. Each genre, be it rap or rock or country, jazz or folk, has given birth to myriad offspring, sub-genres breeding sub-sub-genres like rivers splitting into streams. Among these, there stands Heavy Metal, a colossus that has, over the span of four decades, become a thing both diverse and expressive, a shadowed mirror to the human heart. It speaks in tones of darkness, a symphony of the night, yet it is an art form of many voices, each taking the bones of the old and crafting anew, creating sub-strains and further branches that stretch toward the horizon without end.

And now, in this present time, the heavy metal kingdom is a labyrinth of niches and factions, each claiming its own piece of the sky, so that one might ponder what heavy metal truly is. It is a mosaic, a tapestry woven with threads borrowed from other realms, yet its roots are deep, and to grasp the essence of today's metal, one must turn back to understand the movement itself, the force that drives it beyond mere classification as a genre.

Metal, in its essence, is a movement sculpted in shadow. It is the music of excess, a cacophony of more—more depth, more sound, more fury, more spectacle. Gone is the simplicity, for those who play do so with a mastery that speaks through the strings and skins. It is a movement, too, that bears the mark of illusion, the haze of substances that fueled the mid-seventies, leading artists to the edge of madness and beyond, crafting records that seemed to belong to other worlds, the drugs a veil through which creation was glimpsed. It holds within it a rawness, a ferocity that was unfamiliar in the realm of popular song, which so often shied away from the shadows. The generations that followed drew from this well of darkness, finding kinship with the tumultuous emotions of the Romantic Era, a lineage of passion and despair. 

Consider the words of Helter Skelter, a tune that laid bare the shadowed side of the Beatles, a descent and ascent that mirrored the wild dance of the mind under the spell of substances. This song, some say, stands as one of the forebears of Heavy Metal itself, an answer to the Stones' own dark offering, a declaration that the Beatles too could summon the weight of thunder, and so it found its place upon The White Album.

In a time before the Surrealists laid their brushstrokes upon the canvas of dreams, Henri Rousseau stood alone, a solitary figure crafting visions from the depths of his own soul. The year was 1910, and in his painting The Dream, Rousseau conjured not just the image of a woman transfixed by the marvels of an ethereal land but wove into its fabric the essence of his own aspirations and desires. For within that lush jungle, Rousseau's yearning for recognition and acclaim by his peers and the art world at large lay entwined with the foliage. His journey was fraught with the quiet turmoil of choosing between the mimicry of established forms for acceptance and the uncharted path of creative independence.

To peer into the heart of The Dream, one must first wander through the shadowed corridors of Rousseau's life. Born on May 21, 1844, in the quiet town of Laval, France, he was the son of a tinsmith, a man who enjoyed the modest comforts of bourgeois life (Shattuck 47). Rousseau was untouched by the formal teachings of artistry, laboring instead under the yoke of the gabelou, the municipal toll service, until he found himself at forty, wrongly dubbed a douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). Tragedy cast a long shadow over his days, the loss of his first wife, Clémence, and eight infant children leaving him with but one daughter, Julia, and a heart heavy with grief (Shattuck 49). It was to the canvas he turned, seeking solace and rebirth amidst the pigments.

Unlike his contemporaries who romanticized the peasant life, Rousseau painted with the simplicity and sincerity of the folk, driven by the dreams common to his kind. His quest for acceptance was a natural desire, one amplified by his lack of formal education and the lateness of his start in a world brimming with younger, celebrated talents. It was not until the likes of Matisse began to rise that Rousseau's art found its way into the light. Jan Gordon, in Modern French Painters, draws a line between the two: Matisse, who feared the mundane, and Rousseau, who longed for his art to be conventional enough to secure a place in the Artiste Français (92). And so, Rousseau's brush moved, caught between worlds, painting his dreams with the hope of finding his place among them.

The old thinkers, long given to pondering, have often drawn a line twixt the realms of ethics and aesthetics, a bridge between truth and beauty. There’s a deep-seated reason for this, like the poet Keats murmured in his ode upon that ancient urn, where he spoke of beauty and truth as if they were one and the same. In the world, much is learned through books and the hard hand of experience, yet there lies a knowledge of ethics and aesthetics that seems to spring forth unbidden, needing no teacher's voice. These aren't mere prescriptions, but rather descriptions of the world’s order. Our musings on what is moral or what is beautiful oft become pursuits to understand why a painting captivates or why a deed rings true, rather than setting down laws for art or conduct.

Critiques of art or ethics falter, never grasping the whole of what makes something good or beautiful. Take, for instance, that enigmatic smile of the Mona Lisa; one might speak of its lines, its shadows, its place in the heart of culture, but these alone cannot capture why it grips the soul. When asked of a beloved piece of art or tale, folks often say there’s just something about it, hinting at a truth that eludes the grasp of words. Art and morals resist reduction, as Flannery O'Connor once said, for a story speaks truths that plain statements cannot. Even when we lay bare every facet of a tale, something ineffable remains. Ethics shares this quality. Wittgenstein once whispered of ethics as a thing that cannot be spoken, a transcendental force. It’s this elusive something, this je ne sais quoi, that grants both art and morality their power, binding them in their shared transcendence.

Morality and art walk hand in hand, for they touch us at a level beyond mere explanation, like the noumenon Kant spoke of. They move us where words stumble and fail. This bond is even more pronounced in literature, where, as McKean observed, its moral heart sets it apart from other arts. While moral standards might seem unfitting for music, they are woven into literature as they are into life itself. Living demands values, and literature holds our interest precisely because of the values it unveils.

In the present age, Germany stands as a formidable entity, a nation forged in unity with a culture as diverse as the landscapes it spans, from the shadowy folds of the Bavarian Alps in München to the northern reaches by the Baltic in Kiel. This cultural tapestry weaves itself through Köln on the banks of the Rhine, stretching across the heart of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden upon the Elbe. Such a singular culture springs from myriad origins, a confluence of tribes and histories that bore the Germany we now behold.

The land of Germania, ancient and storied, is the cradle from which the Germans arise. The very name stirs dispute among the learned, tangled in the annals of history. Tacitus once wrote of a tribe, the Tungrians, who bore the name German before ever they crossed the Rhine to clash with the Gauls. So claimed the historian in a distant age. And before him, Caesar, in his chronicles of the Gallic Wars, uttered the word "Germanus" to mark the tribes who dwelt beyond his reach, ever skirmishing across the river's breadth. He borrowed this name from the Gauls to delineate those he had conquered from those yet unconquered. The true origin remains shrouded, some say a neighborly term in the Gaulish tongue, while others muse on the spear, the ger, or the Old Irish cry, garim, that spoke of a people boisterous in battle.

Tacitus, in his account from AD 98, "De Origine et situ Germanorum," mused upon the Germans' beginnings, suggesting they were untouched by foreign mingling. "I should regard them as aboriginal," he wrote, "and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse." Who, he pondered, would forsake the temperate climes of Asia or Africa for the wilds of Germania, with its harsh skies and dour visage, unless it were indeed his home?

And what Roman, in possession of the world's bounty, would trade the grandeur of Rome for the untamed expanse of Germania? None but the legions, driven by conquest, seeking goods to haul back to their empire's heart. From time to time, they ventured forth, their campaigns in those lands brief and often returning them to Rome's embrace. Meanwhile, the Germanic tribes, emerging in the first century's midst, lingered at the empire's edge. They bartered their harvests and lent their strength to Rome's legions, straddling the line between alliance and independence. (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

In the theater of Twelfth Night, the masks we wear might shelter us for a spell, but they demand a reckoning. A man or woman might craft a new face to wear, but the danger lies in the wearing of it too long. For should one cling too dearly to such deception, they might find themselves estranged from their own soul. The shedding of a false skin comes with its own perils, and in the casting off, one might stand alone, alienated from kin and friend alike. The choice then falls upon the deceiver, to hold fast to the truth of themselves or to preserve the fragile bonds with those around them. For the revelation of deceit is a coin with two faces, some might shrug and carry on, while others would storm and rail against the perceived betrayal.

The play casts a particular light on the tangle of deception in matters of gender, raising the question that gnaws at the heart: why does one abandon their own visage for another? In Viola’s plight, the reason is plain as day. She dons her disguise not for trickery’s sake but as a shield against the unknown dangers of a foreign shore. Her words speak of necessity, a captain and a cloak to veil her maidenhood and safeguard her path: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…”

Yet, this guise, while a bulwark, serves also as a wall, cutting her off from her sisters, leaving her adrift without the solace of shared womanhood. Worse still, her mask is so complete that Olivia, mistaking the semblance for truth, entwines her heart with Viola’s. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” And further, there lies the unspoken bond with Orsino, a thread stretched taut by hidden desires: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.”

A modern eye might see in this a tale of how deception unravels the knots of hidden emotions, forcing the likes of Olivia and Orsino to face shadows they never knew. Does Olivia love a man because she sees a man, or is there a deeper truth she dares not name? Yet, the ease with which she turns her affections from Cesario to Sebastian suggests a simpler parody, a reflection of those who place trust in appearances alone. Her words to Viola, “A sister, you are she,” reveal a heart that shifts with the tides, from lover to kin, as if the mask itself had drawn a line between them. 

And so, the play dances on, a mirror held up to the fractures of identity and desire, a world where the truth is both a burden and a blessing.

The annals of German dominion over foreign lands bear witness to a severity that has not gone unnoticed, especially in the dark recesses of history where the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama peoples lies, buried but not forgotten, amidst the arid expanses of German South West Africa. Yet to cast one's net so wide as to catch the entirety of an empire within a single narrative is folly. The German colonial empire sprawled across diverse lands, each holding its own tale of governance and policy, its own way of educating those under its shadow. It was a patchwork of intentions and executions.

When the British unfurled their flag over German East Africa, now known as Tanganyika, in the year 1919, they discovered a populace not unfamiliar with letters and learning, a testament to the German efforts in education. Kamerun and other colonies too bore the marks of an educational legacy that garnered praise from the chroniclers of the time. But South West Africa, present-day Namibia, stood apart, a land where the sun baked the earth and the minds of its native people were left largely untouched by the hands of formal education. The government there had turned its gaze away, leaving missionary societies to the task with scant support, while it poured resources into the schooling of its own kind, building state schools for Europeans and tightening its grip on the missionary endeavors.

This divergence bore its fruit in the years that followed the German retreat. Where other colonies could count among their numbers a host of literate and learned Africans, South West Africa remained a land of silence and illiteracy for the native majority.
